user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseGetInfo(osal_id_t timebase_id, OS_timebase_prop_t *timebase_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *           record;
    int32                          return_code;
    osal_objtype_t                 objtype;
    OS_object_token_t              token;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *timebase;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(timebase_prop);

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    memset(timebase_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_timebase_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, timebase_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_timebase_table, token);
        timebase = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, token);

        strncpy(timebase_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(timebase_prop->name) - 1);
        timebase_prop->creator               = record->creator;
        timebase_prop->nominal_interval_time = timebase->nominal_interval_time;
        timebase_prop->freerun_time          = timebase->freerun_time;
        timebase_prop->accuracy              = timebase->accuracy_usec;

        return_code = OS_TimeBaseGetInfo_Impl(&token, timebase_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimeBaseGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
    uint32    nominal_interval_time;
    uint32    freerun_time;
    uint32    accuracy;
} OS_timebase_prop_t
...
int32 OS_TimeBaseGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_timebase_prop_t *timer_prop)
{
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment in OS_TimeBaseGetInfo (or the provided related definitions) modifies a pointer parameter itself. The function parameters are: timebase_id (by value) and timebase_prop (pointer). The code does not reassign timebase_prop (no statements like timebase_prop = ...). All operations on timebase_prop modify the object it points to (memset, strncpy, and field assignments), which is allowed by Rule 17.8. Passing timebase_prop to OS_TimeBaseGetInfo_Impl only passes the pointer; the impl provided returns immediately and does not modify its pointer parameter variable. The OS_CHECK_POINTER macro only tests for NULL and does not assign to the parameter. Other uses of pointers in the additional code (e.g., OS_ObjectIdGetById with token, or OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET using &(tok)) operate on object contents or local variables and do not reassign function pointer parameters. Therefore there are no fragments that warrant investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
